en.value: Expressing how we feel - Verb "to be"
This unit is all about asking and answering the question "How are you?". Here are some of the phrases we'll learn:
This has a similar meaning to "How is it going?".
This has a similar meaning to "Not bad, thanks.".
Instead of repeating the question "How are you?", we can say "How about you?". Have a look at the short conversation below.
This is similar in meaning to "I'm not great.".
"I'm good." has a similar meaning to "Fine, thanks.".
Select the answer you hear in the audio.
What can we say instead of repeating the question "How are you?".
Match the expression to its translation.
Let's have another look at all the expressions we've learned:
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
Listen and select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
Select the positive words to reply to "How are you?".
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
Select the words in the correct order.
Fill in the gap using the audio.
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
Complete the expression you've just learned using the image.

Let's learn our first verb!  A verb expresses an action or a state, and every full sentence contains at least one. 

"To be" is the most common verb in English. We use it to identify people / things and give information. In this unit we're going to use it to create our first short sentences in English!
Read and listen to the sentence containing the verb "to be".
Select the different forms of the verb "to be" in each sentence.
The verb "to be" changes depending on the person or thing we are talking about. Here are the different forms of the verb "to be":
This sentence contains the verb "to be".
Do you remember? It's quite common to join two words together in English to make a "short form" or "contraction". We can do this by using an apostrophe.
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
Complete the sentence with the correct form of the verb "to be".
Complete the sentence with the short version of "they are".
Respond to the question: How are you?
Hi! I'm not bad, thanks. I'm a little tired. And you?
